thread.title: Day before Umpqua college shooting, state police leader called for school tip line, security database
thread.title_full: Day before Umpqua college shooting, state police leader called for school tip line, security database | OregonLive.com

author: Maxine Bernstein | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Day before Umpqua college shooting, state police leader called for school tip line, security database
text:
The afternoon before the mass shooting at Umpqua Community College, the head of Oregon State Police briefed state lawmakers about the progress of a statewide database of school floor plans and safety protocols.
State Police Superintendent Richard Evans reported that a work group of law enforcement, firefighters and educators was researching what vendor would be best to help create the database.
The group also is working to restart a school safety tip line, he said. The state Department of Justice instituted the line after the 1998 school shooting at Springfield's Thurston High School , but it was later eliminated in budget cuts.
Evans cited an email forwarded to state police last month that identified an online threat made by a man who wrote that he intended to kill people at two Portland-area Christian schools.
"That came through on an email system that morning. By the afternoon, we identified that felon,'' Evans told lawmakers. "The only way we got that is through an email system.''
The tip line is especially important, Evans said. He estimated that 81 percent of the time, someone else knew of a school shooting threat and 93 percent of the time that someone was a peer.
Candlelight vigil held for victims of UCC shooting A candlelight vigil was held Thursday night at Stewart Park in Roseburg for the victims of the Umpqua Community College shooting earlier in the day.
State police are seeking requests for proposals to set up the tip line, he told lawmakers from the state House and Senate Judiciary Committees.
"If our kids aren't safe in school, we fail,'' Evans said. "It's our number one recommendation to the committee for school safety.''
At the same time, the group is looking at using a database similar to the West Virginia Safe Schools Homeland Security Network, he said. It could be downloaded for free. Officials from West Virginia are scheduled to come to Oregon this month to share information on it.
He also said school districts should adopt threat assessment plans similar to that used by Marion County officials.
"Marion County is the national model,'' Evans said, noting that it has had success defusing bullying, destructive behavior and other threats. "There's other counties across Oregon where there's absolutely nothing,'' he said.
On Wednesday afternoon, Evans concluded his address to the legislative committees, "We have to keep our kids safe. The Reynolds shooting is a stark reminder how quickly these things can unfold."
Hours later, 50 members of the state police force rushed to help the Douglas County Sheriff's Office and other agencies respond to a mass killing on Roseburg's Umpqua Community College campus, where a gunman killed nine and wounded seven others before dying in a shootout with police.
